article_title: These holiday events would make even Scrooge enjoy the season
article_text:
The Original Dickens Carolers sing holiday songs during the 2013 Loveland Tree Lighting at the Loveland Recreation Center downtown. Last year's event included visits with Santa and Mrs. Claus, horse-drawn carriage rides, caroling and a bell choir. ( Jenny Sparks / A&E Spotlight )

As the weather cools down, the lights go up and the holiday action across the Front Range picks up.

You can find something seasonal to do every weekend from now until Christmas — and many days in between. From seasonal stories to Santa sightings to song and dance, there are many options to get you in the spirit.

Here are some of the most exciting holiday events in Northern Colorado:

LOVELAND

Loveland starts to exhibit its festive holiday spirit and colorful celebrations as soon as the day after Thanksgiving.

From the red and white lights that glitter on Fourth Street to the lit-up decorations at Benson Sculpture Park Garden and Dwayne Webster Veterans Park, Loveland residents are getting into the spirit of the holidays.

Children wave to the crowd from the Precision Auto Body and Glass float during the 2013 Longmont Parade of Lights. (Cliff Grassmick / A&E Spotlight)

This is the second year the Winter Holiday Council will light up Benson Park with deer and tin soldiers and Christmas bears. They have added a few extra decorations to the mix this year, including a set of train cars and 6-foot tall snowflakes.

The downtown Loveland holiday tree lighting and community sing-along are both events not to be missed. With music and hot drinks to go around, the events will include Christmas carols and camaraderie.

Loveland Lights is also a featured event every year at the Loveland Public Library, with events like the gingerbread challenge, model railroad and "Find the Nutcracker" contest.

Holiday events not to miss:

Light up Loveland Carolers, Santa Claus and cookies by the Winter Holiday Council as they turn on the lights of several displays of decorations, 4 p.m. Friday, Nov. 28, Benson Park Sculpture Garden, 125 E. Seventh St., Loveland.

The Nutcracker Presented by the The Canyon Concert Ballet, 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 29, Rialto Theater Center, 228 E. Fourth St., $23 for adults, $18 for seniors/students and $15 for groups, 970-962-2120, rialtotheatercenter.org.

Frequent Flyers Aerial Dance will perform at The Dairy Center's annual family-friendly event, HoliDairy. (Special to A&E Spotlight)

Holiday Tree Lighting Kick off the holiday season with the downtown Loveland tree lighting with music by the Original Dickens Carolers, horse-drawn carriage rides, photos with Santa, face-painting and food and treat vendors, 4:30-6:30 p.m. Dec. 3, Chilson Recreation Center, Third Street and Washington Avenue, free, 970-962-2410.

Holiday Market Presented by the Odd Fellows, vendors will sell food, artisan and craft items, including Avon, Found Cards, Wildwood Designs, D Terra Essential Oils, Pampered Chef, Kela's Creations and author Zach Wood. And Santa Claus will be on hand for photos, 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Dec. 6, The Majestic Gathering Place, 315 E. Fourth St., 970-308-8756.

Christmas on the Farm The Timberlane Farm Museum, will offer Victorian ornament making, painting wooden ornaments, making old-fashioned Christmas gifts, stringing cranberries and popcorn, wagon rides, music, refreshments and storytelling, 1-4 p.m. Dec. 6, 2306 E. First St., Loveland, $5 per person, $2 for children 5-15, free for children 4-younger, 970-646-2875.

Loveland Lights Celebration Enjoy holiday traditions with events such as a "Find the Nutcracker" contest, model railroad, holiday trees, book and bake sale, gingerbread challenge and musical entertainment, 9 a.m.-6 p.m. Dec. 6 and 1-5 p.m. Dec. 7, Loveland Public Library, 300 N. Adams Ave., 970-962-2665.

Santa Workshop at Centerra Photos with Santa, decorate ornaments, participate in a coloring contest and enjoy cookies and hot cocoa, 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Dec. 6, Dec. 13 and Dec. 20, The Group Inc., 5401 Stone Creek Circle, 970-962-9990, centerra.com.

Community Sing-Along Join Sharon Sheets in an interactive event featuring classic and contemporary holiday tunes, enjoy hot drinks and sweet treats, 2 p.m. Dec. 7, Rialto Theater Center, 228 E. Fourth St., free, 970-962-2120.

Autumn Brazzil, of Berthoud, sings "Jingle Bells" during Downtown Longmont's 2013 tree lighting ceremony. (Lewis Geyer / A&E Spotlight)

"Hallelujah! A Gospel Christmas" The Loveland Choral Society will present the Vocal-EZE octet, Christmas Orchestra and guest soloists, 7:30 p.m. Dec. 12, 2 and 7:30 p.m. Dec. 13 and 2 p.m. Dec. 14, Rialto Theater Center, 228 E. Fourth St., $17, 970-972-2120 or rialtotheatercenter.org. Other holiday celebrations at the Rialto Theater Center include Hazel Miller's "A Christmas from the Heart," Bells of the Rockies' "Ringing in Christmas" and MacKinnon Royal Dance Institute's "A Season of Dance."

Holiday Soiree The Loveland Opera Theatre, with opera singers and violinists performing music, includes appetizers and dessert, 6:30 p.m. Dec. 20 at a home in Loveland. Call for reservations by Dec. 15 (seating is limited to 60), suggested donation $32, lovelandoperatheatre@gmail.com, 970-593-0085.

LONGMONT

Between Thanksgiving and Christmas, Longmont lights up with holiday festivities, decorations and cheer.

The city will become a beacon of holiday joy with the annual tree lighting ceremony, and the less traditional black light show brings colorful song and dance to life on Main Street on Friday, Nov. 28.

Millions of LED lights make Longmont's Roosevelt Park sparkle during the holidays creating the perfect scene for the city's annual Longmont Lights event Dec. 12-13.

Santa will be checking his list while local families enjoy ice skating, holiday crafts, food, hot chocolate and the glittering displays. Lights on Parade will top off the event Dec. 13 with a string of shining displays down Main Street.

Sue Jacobson, Longmont's Recreation Services supervisor, describes the setting as a picturesque Christmas wonderland.

"It is a traditional Norman Rockwell holiday experience in the center of our community," Jacobson said.

Holiday sounds float through the streets of Longmont throughout the season from free performances at the library, an art show and performance at the Longmont Senior Center and "The Nutcracker Ballet," featuring music by Longmont Symphony Orchestra and dancers from the Boulder Ballet at Vance Brand Civic Auditorium.

Longmont's holiday celebrations wouldn't be complete without the opportunity for citizens to give. Annual fundraisers pop up across the city all season, including the 49th Christmas Home tour Dec. 4-6, which benefits the local homeless through Longmont nonprofits.

Holiday events not to miss:

Downtown Longmont Holiday Tree Lighting and Black Light Show Tree lighting ceremony, 7 p.m. Friday, Nov. 28, Sixth Avenue Plaza, Main Street, Longmont, downtownlongmont.com.

Small Business Saturday Residents are encouraged to shop locally with discounts, carolers and holiday decor on Saturday, Nov. 29, downtownlongmont.com.

49th Annual Christmas Home Tour Home tour and holiday fundraiser, VIP Night 4:30-8:30 p.m. Dec. 4, Tours and church activities 9 a.m.-8:30 p.m. Dec. 5 and 9 a.m.-3 p.m. Dec. 6, First Congregational United Church of Christ Longmont, 1500 9th Ave., Longmont, VIP $30, general admission $15 adults, $5 children under 10, 303-776-4940, info@thegiftofhome.org, thegiftofhome.org.

Harp Music at the Library Colorado Celtic Harp Society will perform at 1:30 p.m. and 3:30 p.m Dec. 6, Longmont Public Library, 409 Fourth Ave., Longmont, 303-651-8472, visitlongmont.org.

The Nutcracker Ballet Presented by the Longmont Symphony Orchestra and The Boulder Ballet, 4 p.m. Dec. 6, 2 p.m. Dec. 7, Vance Brand Civic Auditorium, 600 E. Mountain View Ave., Longmont, $21-$33 adults, $18-$25 60-older, $12-$18 18-younger, longmontsymphony.org/html/Nutcracker_Concerts.html.

Music of Joy, Solstice & Noel Cousins of the Muse will perform seasonal music, 7 p.m. and 8 p.m. Dec. 11, Longmont Public Library, 409 Fourth Ave., Longmont, 303-651-8472, visitlongmont.org.

Friday Afternoon Concert & Art Show Sarah Barber, Steve Taylor and Deb Schmit-Lobis perform holiday music, plus the Longmont Artist Guild Art Show, 1:30-4:30 p.m. Dec. 12, Longmont Senior Center, 910 Longs Peak Ave., Longmont, $8, visitlongmont.org.

Longmont Lights Festival of lights and holiday activities, including Santa's Workshop, 5-8 p.m. Dec. 12, 10 a.m.-9 p.m. Dec. 13, Roosevelt Park, Longmont, longmontcolorado.gov.

Lights on Parade Holiday parade, 5 p.m., Dec. 13, Main Street, Longmont, longmontcolorado.gov.

The Secret of Christmas Longs Peak Barbershop Chorus' Christmas concert, 7 p.m. Dec. 19, 2:30 p.m. Dec. 20, First United Methodist Church, 350 11th Ave., Longmont, $10 advance, $12 door, children 12-younger free, longspeakchorus@gmail.com, 720-675-8247, longspeakchorus.org.

Last Chance Gift Fest Holiday art, craft, gift and food sale, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Dec. 21, Boulder County Fairgrounds, 9595 Nelson Road, Longmont, coloradoevents.net.

CARBON VALLEY

The Weld County tri-towns are joining forces for the fourth annual Carbon Valley Holiday Festival on Dec. 6.

Firestone will kick off the festivities with a visit from Santa and Mrs. Claus, live music, crafts and local firefighters.

Dacono will host a tree lighting, more photos with Santa and more crafts and entertainment before the grand finale in Frederick.

The festival of lights, carriage rides and ice carving will complete the day-long festival.

Holiday events not to miss:

Carbon Valley Holiday Festival Holiday activities, food and displays, noon-8 p.m. Dec. 6, times and locations vary see below, firestoneco.gov/holidayfestival.

• Firestone: Santa and Mrs. Claus, crafts, live music, photos with Firemen, noon-4 p.m., Coal Ridge Middle School, 6201 Booth Drive.

• Dacono: Tree Lighting, photos with Santa, crafts, entertainment, 4:30-5:30 p.m., Dacono City Hall, 512 Cherry St.

• Frederick: Festival of Lights, photos with Santa, music, carriage rides, ice carving, 6-8 p.m., Crist Park, 105 Fifth St.

Deck the Downtown Decorating contest between local businesses, Dec. 1-6, downtown Frederick, frederickco.gov/index.aspx?nid=528.

Festive Fridays Holiday activities include sports with Santa, craft night and movie night, 6-8:30 p.m. Dec. 5, Dec. 12 and Dec. 19, Carbon Valley Recreation Center, 701 Fifth Street, Frederick, frederickco.gov/index.aspx?NID=530.

MORE WELD COUNTY

Holiday events not to miss in Johnstown:

Christmas Boutique Crafts, baked goods and a silent auction, 9 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Dec. 6, Johnstown Senior Center, 101 W. Charlotte St. Event also includes a Rotary Club-sponsored Santa visit, 10 a.m.- to 2 p.m. and photos with Santa, $2 donation; lunch, 11 a.m.-1:30 p.m., 970-587-5251.

Great American Christmas with Tony Orlando Orlando will sing holiday favorites and will include such hits as "Candida," "Knock Three Times," "Tie a Yellow Ribbon" and "Sweet Gypsy Rose," Dec. 15-17, Candlelight Dinner Playhouse, $54.50 and up, 970-744-3747, coloradocandlelight.com.

BOULDER

Holiday events not to miss:

The Nutcracker Ballet Presented by the Boulder Philharmonic Orchestra and Boulder Ballet, 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Friday, Nov. 28, 4:30 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 29 and 2 p.m. Sunday, Nov. 30, Macky Auditorium, 285 University Ave., $15-$52, .bouldernutcracker.org.

Firefly Handmade Holiday Market More than 90 artists sell handmade goods, plus children's activities, food trucks, free gift wrapping, food, drinks and more, 10 a.m. Saturday, Nov. 29, Watershed School , 1661 Alpine Ave., $3 fee benefits There With Care, fireflyhandmade.com.

St. Nick on the Bricks Visit Santa, 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturdays through Dec. 20, Pearl Street Mall's Visitor Information Center, free, boulderdowntown.com.

A Broadway Christmas Carol A fresh twist on the Dickens holiday classic ghost story, 2 and 7:30 p.m. on various days, Dec. 4-21, University Theatre at CU Boulder, College Avenue and Broadway, ticket prices vary, colorado.edu.

Holiday Festival 2014 Seasonal music, 7:30 p.m. Dec. 5, Macky Auditorium, 1595 Pleasant St., CU Campus, free, cupresents.org/events/holiday.

Santa's House Meet Santa and more, plus entertainment and a storyteller, 10 a.m.- 4 p.m. Dec. 6, Pi Beta Phi sorority house, 890 11th St., $4 fee goes to charity, santashouseboulder.org.

Historic Boulder's 31st annual Historic Homes for the Holidays tour Featuring the history and architecture of Colorado Chautauqua cottages decorated for the holidays, 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Dec. 6 -7, Colorado Chautauqua, 900 W. Baseline Road, $17-$20, historicboulder.org.

27th annual Lights of December Parade The parade includes a special appearance by Santa, 6 p.m. Dec.6, starting at 15th and Walnut streets, boulderdowntown.com.

25 Days of Grinch-mas Storytime A reading of "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," 11:30 a.m. Dec. 7, upstairs ballroom, Boulder Book Store, 1107 Pearl St., free, boulderbookstore.net.

Holiday Craft Fair Crafts and gifts, 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Dec. 7 and Dec. 14, Unity Church of Boulder, 2855 Folsom St., canned food donations accepted, unityofboulder.com.

HoliDairy Annual family event with variety show, food, crafts, a movie and music, 4-7 p.m. Dec. 7, Dairy Center for the Arts, 2590 Walnut St., $15-$25, 303-440-7826, thedairy.org.

Out Boulder Holiday Party Annual party with food and drink, 7 p.m. Dec. 9, Out Boulder Pridehouse, 2132 14th St., free, outboulder.org.

Christmas with the Kings SIngers The Grammy Award-winning British male sextet's Christmas concert, 7:30 p.m. Dec. 11, Macky Auditorium, 1595 Pleasant St., $20-$65, cupresents.org.

Stories on Stage's "Making Merry" Featuring actors sharing songs and stories of the season, 2 p.m. Dec. 13, Canyon Theatre at the Boulder Public Library, 1001 Arapahoe Ave., Boulder, $28/$15 students, 303-494-0523, storiesonstage.org.

A Winter's World of Song: Steve Mullins and Friends Holiday song and music, 7:30 p.m. Dec. 13, Chautauqua Community House, 900 Baseline Road, $17-$20, chautauqua.com.

Boulder Holiday Gift Festival Featuring art, handcrafted goods, local merchants, live music and more, 11 a.m. Dec. 14, YMCA of Boulder Valley, 2850 Mapleton Ave., free entry.

The Christmas Revels: An Irish Celebration of the Winter Solstice A show celebrating the Celtic traditions of Christmas and rituals of the winter solstice, with fiddling, storytelling, Irish step dancing and singing, 2 and 7 p.m. Dec. 14 and Dec. 20, Boulder Theater, 2032 14th St., $17-$45, rockymountainrevels.org.

Holiday Sing-Along Hosted by Bonnie and Taylor Sims, 4 p.m. Dec. 14 and Dec. 21, Harmony Music House, 2525 Broadway, $5, harmonymusichouse.com.

Silent Night Gala Film debut of the new "Silent Night" opera, 5:30 p.m. Dec. 17, Dairy Center for the Arts, 2590 Walnut St., $125-$150, .

BOULDER COUNTY

If you're looking to add some local flair to your gifts this season, cities throughout Boulder County have tapped into their local artists and craft-makers to present a variety of shopping options.

For example, the Winter Markets at the Lafayette Marketplace, across from Flatirons Church, brings together a long list of vendors on Saturdays through Dec. 20. Pick up local snacks and food from the Longmont Dairy, Sweet Reality Baked Goods and Bjorn's Honey, find unique gifts and then unwind with a massage from Luna Sol Chair Massage or a meeting with Apex Chiropractic, all while enjoying live music.

Lyons' 40th Holiday and Craft Bazaar embraces Boulder County's shop-local culture during the holidays, offering unique homemade gifts while supporting area residents, said Tamara Vega Haddad, Lyons Chamber of Commerce Executive Director.

"The practice of shopping local sustains unique communities like Lyons, which is 100 percent locally owned, reduces environmental impact, creates more good jobs and investment in the Lyons' prosperity and job creations," Vega Haddad said. "Overall, I believe it is a matter of controlling your buying power and sustaining local families and communities."

Holiday events not to miss:

Winter Markets Handmade crafts and gifts and a turkey drive, 11 a.m.- 3 p.m. Saturdays through Dec. 20, Lafayette Marketplace, South Boulder Road, Lafayette, free, farmersmarketlouis.com.

Handmade Holiday Create handmade gifts, supplies included, for Grades 3-5, 4-5:30 p.m. Dec. 2; Grades 6-12, 4-5:30 p.m. Dec. 3, Erie Community Library, 400 Powers St., Erie, free, mylibrary.us.

Christmas Craft Bazaar Local vendors and homemade items, music and food, 9:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m. Dec. 6, Louisville United Methodist Church, 741 Jefferson St., Louisville, free; louisvilleumc.org.

Holiday Mountain Market More than 45 vendors selling handmade crafts and art, music, food, performances, Santa, a silent auction and more, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Dec. 6 and 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Dec. 7, Nederland Community Center, 750 Highway 72 North, Nederland, free, nederlandareaseniors.org, 303-258-0799.

Annual Christmas Fayre with British Flair Presented by Niwot Daughters of the British Empire, holiday shopping with local vendors and photos with Santa, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Dec. 6, Left Hand Grange, 195 Second Ave., Niwot, free, niwot.com

Erie's Holiday Boutique Local vendors, raffles, wine, noon Dec. 6, Vista Ridge Community Center, 2750 Vista Parkway, Erie, free admission.

Searching for Christmas Song and dance by Reverence Academy, 2 p.m. Dec. 14, Angevine Middle School, 1150 S. Boulder Road, Boulder, $12, reverenceweb.com.

40th Lyons Holiday & Craft Bazaar Locally made gift sale, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Dec. 6, 1:30-4 p.m. Dec. 7, Lyons Elementary School Gym, 338 High St., Lyons, facebook.com/lyonsholidaycraftbazaar.

Lyons Lights in Sandstone Park Lights display synchronized to music, 5-6:30 p.m. and 8-9 p.m. Dec. 6, 6-8 p.m. Dec. 7, Dec. 12-14, Dec. 19-21, 5-9 p.m. Dec. 24, Sandstone Park, Lyons, townoflyons.com.

Lyons Annual Holiday Parade of Lights and Fireworks Show Christmas parade and fireworks display, 6:30 p.m. Dec. 6, Main Street, Lyons, townoflyons.com.

Chanukah On Ice Ice skate to Chanukah music, light the menorah, eat jelly donuts, 4 p.m. Dec. 18, Winterskate, 824 Front St., Louisville, $3 adults, $2 kids (ages 4-12), free under 3, plus $4 skate rental, boulderjcc.org.

BROOMFIELD

Tree lightings, dancing and singing. It must be Christmastime.

The holiday season is about to kick into high gear in Broomfield, starting Dec. 5 with the city's annual tree-lighting event, which features choirs and hayrides and a visit from the Jolly Old Elf himself, who is known to arrive by helicopter rather than sleigh.

Holiday events not to miss:

Santa HQ presented by HGTV A modern, digital experience with Santa, featuring ELF-RAY vision, a Naughty O' Nice Meter, photos with Santa, a light show and more, daily through Dec. 24, Flatiron Crossing Mall, 1 W. Flatiron Crossing Drive, photo cost varies, santa-hq.com.

Holiday tree lighting ceremony Visit with Santa Claus, who will arrive by helicopter, singing by local school choirs and hayrides, 6 p.m. Dec. 5, George Di Ciero City and County Building, 1 DesCombes Drive.

Breakfast with Santa The 21st annual Lions Club event features visits with Santa for every child and refreshments, 8-11:30 a.m. Dec. 6, Broomfield Senior Center, 280 Spader Way, free.

Talk to Santa Children ages 2-8 can receive a call from Santa on Dec. 6. Forms available at Broomfield Community Center, 280 Lamar St. or broomfield.org/documentcenter/view/4810. Forms must be returned by 5 p.m. Dec. 5, 303-464-5500.

Holiday Art Show and Sale Support Broomfield artists, 9 a.m.-3 p.m. Dec. 6, Highland Trail, 5085 W. 136th Ave., holidaytouch.com.

Winter Wonderland aerial show Featuring favorite holiday tales performed by Iluminar's three companies: professional, adult student and youth, noon and 7 p.m. Dec. 13, Iluminar Aerial, 2655 Industrial Lane. Three-course dinner served at 7 p.m. show. Tickets for noon show : $15 adults, $10 child (11-younger), family of four $45; 7 p.m. dinner show: $40 adult, $25 child and $115 family of four. Information: iluminaraerial.com.

"Cool Yule! A Jazz Christmas" Presented by Broomfield Symphony Orchestra, featuring Lionel Young and his jazz ensemble, 7:30 p.m. Dec. 13 and 2 p.m. Dec. 14, Broomfield Auditorium, 3 Community Park Road, $10-$23; broomfieldsymphony.org or 303-912-1649.

"A King is Coming to Town" P'zazz Children's Choir and Dynamix Teen Singers' 15th annual Christmas concert, 7 p.m. Dec. 16, Broomfield Auditorium, 3 Community Park Road, $15 adults, $10 seniors/children, 303-466-8275.

Holiday lunch Traditional holiday food and entertainment, noon Dec. 19, Lakeshore Room, Broomfield Community Center, 280 Spader Way, $6-$7.50, pre-registration required (303-464-5526), no refund for cancellations after Dec. 12.

"Snow White/The Step-Sisters' Tale" Two original ballets by Danse Etoile Ballet, 7:30 p.m. Dec. 19-20 and 2 p.m. Dec. 20, Broomfield Auditorium, 3 Community Park Road, $15/$10, brownpapertickets.com/event/894030, mariejose@danseetoile.org.

FORT COLLINS

Santa visits, laser imagery and holiday artisan markets; it's difficult to choose just one signature Fort Collins event over the holidays.

Residents of a mind to enjoy the crisp outdoors can experience the Jingle Bell Run/Walk or the Garden of Lights at the Gardens on Spring Creek. While the Garden involves a more leisurely exploration of the outdoors, it does so by delighting the senses with thousands of twinkly LED lights.

Children who haven't told Santa all their wishes yet can do so at his log cabin in Old Town. And they can express their wishes in English, Spanish or sign language.

Those who haven't experienced the OtterBox Digital Dome Theater at the Fort Collins Museum of Discovery might want to take part of "Let it Snow," a production that includes festive songs made classic by the likes of Frank Sinatra and Chuck Berry, and pairs the music with digital enhancements of visual effects and animation.

Holiday events not to miss:

Let it Snow This 32-minute production features a variety of festive classics by Frank Sinatra, Chuck Berry, Burl Ives and Brenda Lee. There also will be a multimedia finale by the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, a soundtrack that is visually enhanced with thematic animation, laser imagery, special effects and all-dome scenery, running through Dec. 31, Fort Collins Museum of Discovery's OtterBox Digital Dome Theater, 408 Mason Court, $5 for museum members and $7 for others. in addition to museum admission of $9.50 for adults, $7 for seniors and students, and $6 for ages 3-12, 970-221-6738, fcmod.org.

Santa's Log Cabin Children can visit Santa's log cabin at Old Town Fort Collins, noon-6 p.m. Wednesday-Sunday until Dec. 14 and noon-6 p.m. every day Dec. 14-24, Santa speaks Spanish and sign language, free, 970-484-6500, downtownfortcollins.com/events.

Holiday Artisan Market More than 100 local artists will present handmade gifts and foods, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Friday, Nov. 28, and Saturday, Nov. 29, Fort Collins Senior Center, 1200 Raintree Drive, $1; ages 12 and under free, 970-221-6644.

NightLights Tree Lighting Realities for Children also will offer music, hot soup, dessert buffet, Santa, photos taken with the 1919 Dodge Brothers touring car from the 1946 film, "It's a Wonderful Life," 6-7 p.m. Monday, Dec. 1, on the front lawn of First Presbyterian Church, 531 S. College Ave, 970-484-9090, giveanightlight.com.

The Gardens on Spring Creek Garden of Lights Whimsically decorated gardens lit by tens of thousands of twinkling LED lights, 5-9 p.m. Dec. 5-Jan. 4, 2145 Centre Avenue, fcgov.com/gardens.

Tuba Christmas Tuba and euphonium players will perform traditional Christmas Carols in four-part harmony under the direction of Loveland Mayor Cecil Gutierrez, sing-along encouraged, 2 p.m. Saturday, Dec. 13, Oak Street Plaza, Oak Street and College Avenue, tubachristmas.com.

Jingle Bell Run/Walk The Arthritis Foundation offers family- and pet-friendly 5K chip-timed run and walk event that raises funds to support the 830,000 Coloradoans affected by arthritis. Racers encouraged to dress in costumes and wear bells, 8 a.m. registration, 10:15 5K on Dec. 6, Colorado State University Campus Oval, jinglebellrunnortherncolorado.kintera.org or 720-644-4409.
